With the commercial fast breeder reactor, no planning consent is involved and it is very hard to see how a Government could procedurally have fastened on to this subject in spite of the promise.
The Select Committee on Science and Technology looked at the matter. We decided—using the independence that we possessed—that it was in the public interest that an inquiry should be held. It would, incidentally, perhaps have helped the Government, by taking them away from a dilemma in which they found themselves. At the wish of the Committee, I as Chairman wrote to the Ministers concerned, principally my right hon. Friends the then Secretaries of State for Energy and for the Environment. There is no reason why I should not reveal this to the House now; we have a great desire for open government. I asked my right hon. Friends, with the knowledge of the Committee, how they would view the prospect of the Select Committee on Science and Technology investigating the matter. We had replies which were not particularly favourable to our doing so. However, that did not deter the Committee. We proposed to go ahead. In fact, we had made a start on it before the Dissolution of the last Parliament.
I wonder from this whether the new Select Committee on Energy, or whatever other departmentally related Committee one likes to name, will show the same degree of independence in the future that the subject Committees, because of their nature, have been able to show in the past. I leave that thought with the House.

I have great pleasure in following the hon. Member for Bristol, North-East (Mr.
Palmer) and in joining him in congratulating my hon. Friend the Member for Grantham (Mr. Hogg) on his truly excellent maiden speech. I thought that my hon. Friend wended his way with great clarity and precision through the recommendations of the Committee on Procedure, but I foresee one danger for him. If he should by any lucky chance find himself on any of the new departmentally related Select Committees, I do not think that he will stay there for long. I already hear the putative ministerial voice speaking in my hon. Friend the Member for Grantham—still at this stage ready to answer questions, but not for long. I therefore think that his life on a Select Committee might be rather brief.
My first point is to ask whether Back Benchers—this goes for Back Benchers on both sides of the House, of course—can effectively control executive Ministers who are yesterday's Back Benchers and, perhaps, such are the fortunes of life, tomorrow's Back Benchers—I say that in no party sense, I assure those on the Front Bench—and whether, particularly, we can do this when so many of us are anxious to step into the very shoes of those Ministers.
The right hon. Member for Bristol, South-East (Mr. Benn) referred to members of Select Committees as "Ministersin-waiting". Somebody else said that they had been described in the weekend press as "Ministers manqué". Indeed, those of us who serve on Select Committees might be better if we accepted that we were Ministers manqué. The trouble is that we do not accept that. We still feel that the ministerial mantle might fall on us.
This means that in our approach to Ministers who appear before us on Select Committees—I speak as somebody who in the last Parliament served on the Select Committee on Nationalised Industries under the chairmanship of the hon. Member for Feltham and Heston (Mr. Kerr)—we tread delicately. Because in our future prospects, we are so intertwined with Ministers, I do not believe that these recommendations—and I congratulate my right hon. Friend the Leader of the House on bringing them before the House—are all that important. I do not think that it will make all that much difference to the control of the Executive, whether there are five, six or twelve Select Committees.
I think that much more importance lies not in the machinery which I hope we shall set up following this debate but in the nuts and bolts. By that I refer to Members of Parliament themselves and the independence and skill they can bring to the job.
The first consideration, then, relates to the selection of the members of a Select Committee. I was pleased to hear the remarks of my hon. Friend the Member for Carlton (Mr. Holland) on that subject. I believe that the independence of the members of Select Committees is a matter of prime importance. When the Select Committee on Nationalised Industries had produced its reports on the British Steel Corporation, one of the members of that Committee, the hon. Member for Bedwellty (Mr. Kinnock), was suddenly removed from our team. He disappeared overnight, and we asked ourselves why that had happened. We concluded that the hon. Gentleman had been just a little too good in pursuing Ministers; he had asked too many difficult questions, and we felt that that was why he had been translated. I am glad that he has reappeared on the Opposition Front Bench, and I congratulate him.
The independence of which I speak is necessary not only in a Select Committee itself but on occasions when its reports are debated on the Floor of the House. Our recommendations on the British Steel Corporation were agreed unanimously in the Select Committee, but when it finally came to debating those recommendations on the Floor of the House hon. Members who had been lions upstairs suddenly were converted into rather meek lambs and the motion to approve our reports on the Floor of the House turned into a party political debate and the motion was negatived.
The second consideration is that a Select Committee must be backed up by adequate and well-instructed staff. The Congressional Record for 1975—the last one I have managed to examine—points out that in that year representatives were each allowed to increase their staff to 18 members, and were allowed a salary of $250,000 just to pay their staff. Doubtless that figure has increased greatly since then because of inflation.
We content ourselves too much with half a Clerk and half a professional adviser. If we are to do this new job
which is entrusted to us, there must be suitable funds available both for the staff and for the travel that members of Select Committees think is necessary. I asked a question about this earlier, and I hope that my right hon. Friend, when he replies, will tell us a bit more about how he sees the situation regarding the availability of funds.
It will be most important that Committees should be able to study Bills in draft form. I do not mind whether this is done in Standing Committee or Select Committee. The essential thing is that Back Benchers on both sides of the House should be able to call technical evidence before them at the draft stage of legislation. We get technical back-up now from professional bodies when we are in Standing Committee. We receive briefs from professional bodies with their views on such and such a subject. But, as we all know, we then have the ridiculous pretence of not being able to refer to them directly, and certainly not being able to call in evidence those who have sent us the briefs.
How much better it would be if we could have those witnesses in front of us before the machismo—the virility—of the Minister and his Department has got intertwined with and attached to seeing that a Bill, having had its First Reading, is then passed by the Committee without any amendment whatsoever. That is the present, and so unnecessary situation. It should be avoided in future.
Then there is the question of the time of the hon. Members who sit on the Select Committees. It is impossible for any Member of this House to be intelligent at 10.30 in the morning if he has been up voting until well after midnight—until perhaps three or four in the morning—three or four consecutive nights previously. Let us face the fact that the expert witnesses we want to call before us in Select Committees are all intelligent. They know their jobs. That is why they are there. But they did not go to bed at three or four in the morning on the three or four nights previously.
It is ridiculous for us to feel that we can interrogate the Government Actuary, a nuclear physicist or the chairman of the British Gas Corporation with all the verve and alertness that we need if we
have been flogging through the Lobbies until some late hour the night before.
This brings me to a hobby-horse of mine. I hope that my right hon. Friend the Leader of the House will take this on board as a future recommendation to the House. I think that the time will come when Members of Parliament, after the main vote at 10 p.m., must be able to pre-record their vote for the rest of the night's business.
No, no.

I know that the hon. Member for Fife, Central (Mr. Hamilton) does not agree with me on this, though in the past there have been many things on which we have agreed. Let me put the advantages of this idea to him.
First, all those who were not interested in the business would be able to go home and prepare for the interrogation of expert witnesses the following morning. But even more important than that is the fact that those with an interest in the business after 10 p.m.—and on this occasion we are to go on voting, I am told, until three or four in the morning—would be able to go on speaking for the allotted time without having the Whips breathing down their necks saying "Is it not time that you shut up because the lads want to go home?" This is, as we all know, the kind of pressure that Back Benchers are put under at the moment.
There is no more humiliating business for Back Bench Members, on both sides of the House, than being kept around just to vote. For us to be treated as Lobby fodder; for us to be here simply in order to go through the Lobbies—it happens on both sides of the House all the time—in that context, we are not worth £6,000 a year, let alone £12,000 a year.
It would be a useful task for Inmos, that proud child of the National Enterprise Board, to produce a foolproof system—and I stress "foolproof"—to allow hon. Members to record their votes on all the expected Divisions until 2.30 the following afternoon.
Those are the matters which I believe are more important than the number of Select Committees: the time of hon. Members, their independence from the Whips on Select Committees and expert staff to back hon. Members.
I still believe that a far more effective watchdog than any parliamentary Committee would be partial denationalisation. A shareholder will always be more interested than any parliamentary Committee in the successful running of a business. But that is a debate for another night.
We are saying that we have not controlled the Executive well and, therefore, we are bringing in a new system. If the Government go on as their predecessors have behaved and provide many more examples of excessive and uncontrolled expenditure which are not properly monitored, our last state will be worse than our first.
The public will expect us to succeed in the new system. I shall vote for it, with some reservations, and I hope that we shall all do everything we can to ensure that it succeeds. Otherwise, the British people will indeed be disappointed.

I thought that the hon. Member for Mid-Sussex (Mr. Renton) was about to launch himself on a discussion of one of my favourite hobby-horses—the introduction of reasonable hours for the House. It is crazy that we should hold debates at midnight and beyond.
It is remarkable that so many hon. Members have stayed throughout this debate from 3.30 p.m. without food or drink. Perhaps we need our heads examined for still doing that sort of thing. If we had more reasonable hours, that would bring control of Government to the crunch. They could not then extend the hours of debate and keep us here as captives when we are keen to contribute to a debate.
The keenness of hon. Members to take part in this debate and the fact that there is so little opposition to the Leader of the House's proposals are remarkable. I support the plan to set up Select Committees related to individual Departments. Before the general election, my Expenditure Committee covered the Departments of Employment and Health and Social Security. That was a large chunk of work for any Committee to take on board. There were a number of areas with political sex appeal that the Committee could investigate, and it could not concentrate on one Department but had to move from one to the other. That was a mistake.
Having Committees that concentrate on individual Departments is a good idea.
Under our existing system, Select Committees are responsible for looking at Departments' expenditure and they have the power to send for Ministers. I have never known a Minister refuse to attend. Not long ago, my Committee had that august personage the Chancellor of the Exchequer before us and we managed to squeeze out a bit of information that he was not willing to give before. We felt that we had done rather well.
One of the major advantages is that Members themselves can become well-informed about the responsibilities of a particular Department and can acquire a certain amount of expertise, which is a valuable contribution to debates in the House when Bills from that Department are before the House or when hon. Members raise matters on private Members' days.
I therefore welcome the proposal to set up these Select Committees. It is quite an improvement for the Committee to propose that we should have eight full days to debate the reports. That was proposed by the Select Committee but the Leader of the House is not saying anything about it. We are to have these 12 Select Commitees and there are suggested additions. Clearly, eight days would not be sufficient, and I hope that the right hon. Gentleman will take on board the fact that we need to have more opportunities to debate the reports that come to us from the new Select Committees. We must keep pressing him for additional time.
If the Committees are to have additional time in the House, Ministers who have the responsibility to respond to the reports and recommendations they contain must prepare their replies very much more quickly than in the past. It is disgraceful that a Committee that has worked hard for nine months or so—most of the Session—should have to wait perhaps a year or more before a departmental reply is received.
I know that sometimes the reports are rather unacceptable to Ministers. I recall that when my Committee did an investigation into the effects of private practice on the National Health Service and we reported to no less a personage than the present Secretary of State for Industry, then Secretary of State for
Social Services, he did not like our report at all and kept us waiting for more than a year before replying.
Although I and other members of the Committee raised the matter in the House on many occasions, the right hon. Gentleman still continued to defy the Committee—because that was what his attitude meant—and kept us waiting for so long for his reply. That sort of thing does not help to maintain the interest of hon. Members, and I am all in favour of careful selection for the departmentally related Committees to ensure that people are appointed who are really interested in the work of the Department concerned.
There has to be some reciprocity from Ministers, and I hope that the Leader of the House will keep his chaps up to scratch, at any rate better than we managed to keep some of ours up to scratch and better than his predecessors in the last Conservative Government managed to keep their chaps up to scratch.
I refer now to some of the financial arrangements that appear in the report but which have not been included by the Leader of the House in his motion. The report makes strong recommendations for the improvement of the staffing and servicing of the new Committees. All of us would support them because a Committee of this kind cannot operate, with all the work in depth that it does, with one Clerk attached to it and perhaps a share of another Clerk in the Committee Office. That is simply not enough. There is an enormous amount of organisational work, especially if it is a Committee which travels out into the country, as most Select Committees need to. The staffing and servicing for the new Committees must be an improvement on the past.
There is no difficulty in the appointment of specialist advisers for the Committees. I understand that most of the Committees have appointed specialist advisers for the subjects they have been investigating. I say to my hon. Friend the Member for Sheffield, Attercliffe (Mr. Duffy), who left us some few hours ago, that I rather took exception to his remarks about the appointment of male specialist advisers—"maybe a woman", he said. My Committee, which sat up to the general election, had a very distinguished woman professor of epidemiology. She
was one of the three specialist advisers to the Committee, the other two being men.
I urge a less restrictive attitude on the part of the Leader of the House and the Government to the finances which are available to the Committees, and I hope that we shall hear how the right hon. Gentleman proposes to deal with the problem of Committees which wish to travel abroad. The procedure until the general election was that the Select Committee Chairmen prepared their requests, which went via the Chairman of the main Expenditure Committee to that nebulous body the Liaison Committee, which was composed of the Chairman of the Select Committees of the House, including the Public Accounts Committee, the main Expenditure Committee and others. That Committee was given a certain amount of money at the beginning of the Session to finance the journeys of the Select Committees. The case of each Sub-Committee of the Expenditure Committee had to be argued by the Chairman of the main Committee, which was not always as satisfactory as it might have been.
As I understand it, that is no longer the position. Accordingly, I endorse the proposal of the hon. Member for Tiverton (Mr. Maxwell-Hyslop) that finances should be made available to each Select Committee. This is a valuable suggestion. The Committees would then be masters of their own programmes and could plan their journeys, whether at home or abroad, accordingly. This seems to be a very sensible proposal. I hope that we shall hear from the Leader of the House what his alternative is. I think that this is a very important proposal.
No. no.

My hon. Friend the Member for Fife, Central (Mr. Hamilton) does not agree. But he does not agree with a great deal that is said from both sides of the House.
I should like to hear from the Leader of the House how he suggests members of a Select Committee can express the minority view of that Committee. I have read the recommendations of the Procedure Committee on the voting and how the Chairman of a Committee can dispose of his or her vote. But there can remain in rather contested reports a very strong
minority view which insists on being expressed. I am not against that. I was in that position myself when we were reporting on the effect of private practice on the National Health Service. On that occasion the majority view of the Committee went forward as the Committee's report with all its recommendations. But at the meeting of the main Expenditure Committee, when the report had to be accepted or otherwise, I had the opportunity of moving as amendments to the report all the proposals that I and some of my hon. Friends on the Committee had put forward but which had been defeated. I am very pleased to say that many of those recommendations then became the basis of my party's policy, when in Government, for dealing with private pay beds in NHS hospitals.
One aspect of the report disturbs me greatly. It was referred to notably by the hon. Member for Havant and Waterloo (Mr. Lloyd) and the hon. Member for Eastleigh (Mr. Price). It is the decision that there should no longer be a Select Committee on Science and Technology but that the work should be carried out by all the other departmentally related Committees. This is a very bad decision.
We are facing an industrial revolution as a result of the rapid introduction of new scientific methods which will affect every industrial enterprise in the country in one way or another. Even simple ordinary jobs will be eliminated by the new techniques now being introduced. Clerical and warehouse jobs, stock control and replacement will all be replaced by electronic machines. Computers and digital electronic equipment will both displace many people and at the same time make great demands on our human resources. We shall need equipment, training and retraining, new education and newly trained people—different kinds of people—to design and to use the new equipment.
Telecommunications, television and transport will be affected. There is bound to be a revolution in motor car design and the internal combustion engine, probably more rapidly than many people imagine, as the search for new fuels continues. The Department of Education and Science, the Department of Industry, the Department of Employment, with its TOPS and youth opportunities pro-
gramme, the National Enterprise Board and the Manpower Services Commission will be affected. The engineering industry training board, many other training boards and the whole range of private industry will be involved.
I asked the Secretary of State for Education and Science what action he intended to take to increase the courses available in secondary schools in computer science. The reply stated: The balance and the breadth of curriculum in schools, however, remains a matter for local education authorities and the schools themselves. That does not display much drive. To my question to the Secretary of State for Employment asking whether he was satisfied with the existing level of retraining courses in micro-chip technology, the reply was: Steps are therefore being taken, particularly by the Manpower Services Commission, to encourage industry to increase training and retraining in areas of known shortage. The Government are keeping the situation under careful review. That does not get us very far. More encouragement is needed in this serious situation.
I asked the Secretary of State for Education and Science if he would see that there was at least one British-built micro-computer in every secondary school within the next three years. A microcomputer has existed in every secondary school in France for the last three years. The reply by the Under-Secretary of State said: The provision of computing facilities for schools is primarily a matter for individual local authorities". But they are not given the money. The answer goes on to say that The possibility"— only a possibility— of a programme to promote awareness of microelectronics in schools and colleges is under consideration and one aim of such a programme could be"— not should be, or will be— to foster and advise on the use of computers. Finally, when I asked the Secretary of State for Industry what direct action he intended to take to increase Great Britain's expenditure on industrial research and development, I was told: The level of expenditure by industry on research and development is primarily a matter for individual firms".
I hope that some of the Select Committees will see that Ministers are kicked in the right direction and that some sense of urgency is brought to these matters. The Government are responsible for seeing that resources are made available for research and development. We compare badly with our international competitors. France, Germany, Japan and the United States are all spending more in this sphere. There are many interesting fields of investigation for the Select Committees when they are set up.

I hope to speak only for a few minutes. It is right to pay tribute to the work of the Select Committee on Procedure for the whole range of its recommendations. We are looking at only one section of that range tonight. I am glad to hear from my right hon. Friend the Leader of the House that the recommendations tonight are to be considered only as a first instalment.
One concern about tonight's recommendations relates to the handling of draft Bills. I understand that the new-style Select Committees will have the opportunity to look at Bills in an investigative manner for a few days immediately before the traditional Committee stage. I hope that the new Committees will not be precluded from examining draft Bills. We may need more time to consider them than the new arrrangements allow.
I shall give an example from my experience as Chairman of a Standing Committee. The Housing (Homeless Persons) Bill came before that Committee but it soon became apparent that the Bill would have to be amended to give priority to certain categories of the homeless. At that point the Committee procedure broke down because it was so much of a straitjacket that it was not possible to consider the issue properly. The matter was deferred until Report stage. It would have been better had the appropriate departmental Committee had a chance to examine the issue. I hope that my right hon. Friend the Leader of the House will assure us that the new Committees will be able to examine draft Bills if they wish.
I am also worried about the vexed question of the power to send for persons
and papers. We had experience of this under the old Select Committee system. The words do not mean what they say. We have the power to send for some papers but not others. We have the power to send for certain people but not others. I am disappointed that this wording is to remain under the new arrangements.
I accept the sincerity of my right hon. Friend when he says that he will do his best to ensure that Government Departments co-operate with the Select Committees. But, with respect to my right hon. Friend, he cannot bind his successors. The proposal is no substitute for a written assurance.
The first special report from the Procedure Committee states that … it is desirable that every select committee having power to send for persons, papers and records should, notwithstanding the practice of the House, have power to order the attendance to give evidence to them of Ministers of the Crown who are Members of this House, and to order the production of papers and records by Ministers of the Crown … We have had experience in the Expenditure Committee of papers which were not forthcoming. The hon. Member for Fife, Central (Mr. Hamilton) recalled correctly that one paper was not made available to the Education Sub-Committee of the Expenditure Committee, though, to rub salt into the wound, it was made available to the OECD. That is a slight which is not forgotten easily. There are other similar examples.
I turn to the question of the timing of Government observations on reports. It is not good enough that there should be inordinate delay. That means that the impetus is lost and the Government are given an excuse for inactivity. A report from the Expenditure Committee on the Charity Commission published in 1975 has not yet been the subject of Government observation. Marvellous reasons have been given, but after that length of time the excuses wear thin. I should like an assurance that there will be a different approach in the new system.
The new set-up gives us good opportunities to strengthen the position of Back Benchers and the power of the House. In that sense I disagree with tonight's speech by the right hon. Member for Manchester, Ardwick (Mr. Kaufman). I am sure that we have much to gain from the new system, but I hope that it will not be
vitiated by the weaknesses that I have outlined.

Like the hon. Member for Plymouth, Drake (Miss Fookes), I support the setting up of Select Committees to cover each Department of State. But, like her, I have some reservations. There can be no question but that over recent times there has been a sharp decline in the power of the legislature compared to the Executive, and that within the Executive the degree of ministerial control over the Civil Service has been much less close and much less comprehensive than is often supposed, and it now needs to be supplemented.
I think that the former is well understood, but the latter is much less so. I should therefore like to concentrate upon that as a major justification for these reforms. To paraphrase Dick Crossman, the power of the Civil Service has been growing steadily in recent years; it is still growing and it needs to be cut back. Grounded as it always has been in its permanence and continuity, it has been growing largely because of its huge organisational coverage over the assembly and the use and the filtering of information in a more technological age.
I accept that the slant of this power is not directly conspiratorial, and is not overtly anti-reformist. But it is certainly ideologically very much directed towards the maintenance of the status quo. These trends have steadily whittled the doctrine of a Minister's responsibility for his Department into not exactly a myth, because that is not true, but certainly into something of a facade.
Apart from the enormous staffs in modern Departments, about the vast majority of whose work no Minister could be, or could possibly even have the time to be, aware, the ministerial role has been dissipated by a whole variety of factors. These include the long time scale of many Government involvements—for example, in aerospace or in State pension schemes—and the complexity of many technological issues, whether concerning nuclear reactors, the Channel tunnel or whatever. Inevitably, therefore, it seems that under the present system the handling of many key issues in practice devolves into the hands of Home Office officials.
Another relevant development here has been the almost complete eclipse of the public body of inquiry—the Royal Commission—by the interdepartmental committee of officials. As the New Statesman revealed in a recent article, there are at least 35 Cabinet sub-committees and, underpinning them and to some extent perhaps pre-empting them, no fewer than 60 or 70 official committees.
Of course, in one sense the development of in-house skills of this kind is a very good thing, but it raises a number of important and so far unanswered questions about the political balance of power between the State bureaucracy on the one hand and elected Ministers on the other. Officials hold the power of the drafter and too often draft papers without consultation with the Minister. By the time a Minister receives the papers, it is virtually impossible for him to unpick an agreed Whitehall package. As Dick Crossman said in his memoirs, I have yet to see a Minister prevail against an interdepartmental official paper without the backing of the Prime Minister, the First Secretary or the Chancellor. Another factor which undermines the political accountability of the Civil Service is the expertise of officials in employing the Whitehall network. As we know from experience, this involves such interesting devices as officials contacting opposite numbers in other Whitehall Departments to enable them to brief their Ministers against their own Minister, where the latter has taken a line which may be outside the broad Whitehall consensus. That, I submit, is the context for a real debate about the nature of executive power and what is required to regulate it. The re-establishment of genuine democratic control over the bureaucracy demands many reforms. I think that the setting up of these departmentally related Select Committees is an important one, but it certainly is not enough.
There are many other necessary reforms which in my view need to be established including the rights of Ministers. It should not simply be civil servants who are responsible for all top Civil Service appointments or at least have a major say in them. Another reform is the establishment of the right of Ministers to bring into office with them up to perhaps a dozen political advisers, not just one or two as at present, who are authorised to
sit on departmental and interdepartmental official committees and to pursue the Minister's political priorities where it counts.
A third reform which has been much talked about, but has not yet been achieved, is a freedom of information Act. But, given the entrenched strength of the bureaucracy, even the proposal to set up Select Committees shadowing Departments of State, important though this is, essential though I think it is, would certainly be invalidated if they were not given real teeth.
First, I do not think that it is right that the emphasis should be—as with Select Committees in the past—simply on expenditure and the need to control it. The purpose of these Committees is surely to ferret out what the Executive is up to, systematically to question it and, above all, to influence departmental policy thinking before it becomes a fait accompli. This is, as others have said, perhaps most important in the preparation of legislation.
I ask the Minister, as other hon. Members have done, whether he will give a guarantee that these new Committees will be able to consider, for example, the substantive content of Bills before they are published.
Secondly, and repeating what others have said, because I want to add my voice to it, it is absolutely necessary that a Committee should have powers to enforce the appearance of Ministers and the production of documents. It really is not good enough for the Leader of the House merely to give us a pledge that Ministers will co-operate. That did not prevent the non-attendance of Mr Harold Lever in defiance of the Expenditure Committee in 1976.
That was your Government.

I was talking about Mr. Harold Lever not as an individual but as a Minister. I suggest that the hon. Member for Honiton (Mr. Emery) would be very unwise if he did not regard that as a precedent for what may well happen on sensitive issues dealt with by the Committees which his Government are setting up.
It is no use saying that some relevant papers are confidential because, subject to proper safeguards in matters of national security or commercial confidentiality, they can be taken in secret session. On the question of the powers of enforcing the presentation of papers, it is no good hiding behind the anomaly involving whether a Department happens to be headed by a Secretary of State. Surely no one wants to go through the facade we had in February of last year to get the papers from the chairman of the British Steel Corporation.
Thirdly, will the Committees have a well-paid and extensive secretariat and research back-up? The odd part-time appointee, however good he is, simply will not be good enough. Full-time, expert staffs will be absolutely essential.
Lastly, I believe that there is a need for adequate, guaranteed parliamentary time for debating the reports of these Committees. At present the lack of any formal provision of parliamentary time by the Leader of the House for debating these reports—I also believe that a mere eight days as recommended by the Select Committee is quite inadequate—is a serious omission. I ask the right hon. Gentleman to give us a specific undertaking when he replies that adequate parliamentary time will be provided for debating most, if not all, of the Committee reports on substantive motions.
This proposal is only one step along the way, although an important one. There are a number of other important proposals from the same Select Committee for changing the hours of sitting in this Chamber and giving Standing Committees the right to examine witnesses before they get down to considering the clauses of a Bill. I hope that the Government will agree that these two issues should be put to an early free vote of the House, since the proposals being considered tonight do no more than merely set the momentum of reforming procedure in this Chamber and in Whitehall. I believe that this process still has a long way to go.

I have been listening carefully to the debate. I propose to introduce my own procedural reform by speaking for only 35 seconds. I do not propose to discuss the issues. I
simply point out that no amount of computers, silicon chips or scientific changes will solve the problems of Rhodesia, the Middle East and Northern Ireland.
On the question of the power of the House, when I was a junior Minister my right hon. Friend the Member for Ebbw Vale (Mr. Foot), together with the right hon. Member for Down, South (Mr. Powell), kyboshed the plans of a Labour Government with a majority of almost 100 to reform the House of Lords. I learnt then of the power of this Chamber on considered argument on a most important issue.
I also learned as a junior Defence Minister that my right hon. Friend the Member for Leeds, East (Mr. Healey), whom I regard as one of the great Defence Ministers since Haldane, could, on his knowledge of the Department and without the aid of political advisers, get what he wanted. That is what matters, and it is rather different from Select Committees.
I have learnt in the last week that what the Leader of the House is offering tonight is evolution. What happens after that is up to this House. What happens tonight on the amendments is up to the right hon. Gentleman when he puts his case to us, having listened diligently to the debate since 3.30 p.m.

My first pleasant duty is to congratulate my hon. Friend the Member for Grantham (Mr. Hogg) on his distinguished maiden speech. What a remarkable political city Grantham is. There must be something in the air that produces one political triumph after another. The maiden speech of my hon. Friend has impressed all who heard it and has added further lustre to a family political tradition of high distinction.
We have had an excellent debate, and by and large the Government's proposals have been warmly welcomed. I am particularly grateful to the right hon. Member for Leeds, South (Mr. Rees) for what he said in his opening speech, and then again for his very generous remarks at the end. I have heard nearly all the speeches, except for three. I have sat here, along with other hon. Members, for no less than 10 hours. I do not think that I have ever been in the
House for a longer stretch before. The three speeches that I missed were faithfully reported to me by my hon. Friend the Under-Secretary of State for Education and Science, who came in and resumed his old role on my behalf.
If one wants a well-attended debate, one must do two things—have a subject that really concerns the House and have a free vote. The idea that one can get hon. Members to the House only by a three-line Whip is disproved completely by looking around the Chamber today. There are more hon. Members here tonight than there are at times when a draconian three-line Whip is imposed.
The only discordant note came from my old friend the hon. Member for Fife, Central (Mr. Hamilton).
Discordant?

It was not discordant by the hon. Gentleman's standard but was discordant by anyone else's. When the hon. Gentleman opposes something, I regard that as the final accolade and the signal to go ahead, in the conviction that one is right.
There has been some vestigial suspicion of the Government's motives in putting forward the proposals. Motives are personal things, and I cannot look into the minds of ministerial colleagues. I can speak only for myself. Both in Opposition and in Government I have been a believer in parliamentary reform, in the rights of Back Benchers and in the importance of the Select Committee structure proposed by the Select Committee on Procedure. I believe that while the proposed measures will not solve all our parliamentary problems, they constitute a decisive shift of the centre of power from Whitehall back to Westminster.
My right hon. Friend the Member for Taunton (Mr. du Cann) pressed me about the future. He asked "What about the rest of the report?", as did a number of other right hon. and hon. Members. I consider the motions to be only the first instalment, but a massive first instalment, of the Committee's proposals, covering almost one-third of them. It is the "premier pas qui coûte." [HON. MEMBERS: "The right hon. Gentleman is showing off."] It is not showing off, it comes naturally. The House should be thankful that that quotation is French, not Latin.
To reach this point has required a concentrated effort. It has required consultations with colleagues in the Cabinet and in the House, with Back Benchers of all parties. There will be a great deal more work in getting the Committees set up, obtaining the staff, having the members appointed and so on. Therefore, this instalment still requires a great deal of effort to bring it to a successful conclusion.
I have also announced today proceedings with regard to the Exchequer and Audit Department. A review is going on with a view to legislation. I was asked what books the Committee would be able to look at. That is one of the matters which is being investigated. The duty will be to find out where the books have been cooked—for that matter, what cooks to book—and other related subjects.
There is a further step. There are 50 or so recommendations of the Procedure Committee left: various pleas for limited time for speeches in certain circumstances, at certain times of the day, changes in the hours of the House, that the House should rise on Friday at, say, 9.30—[HON. MEMBERS: "Oh."] I am sorry. I have slipped into talking of 9.30 p.m. I meant beginning the sitting at 9.30 a.m. There are recommendations about the Public Bill procedure, which are extremely difficult, controversial proposals about which there will have to be wide discussions.
We have made a start. Once one embarks on a path one must go forward, and we must follow the path of parliamentary reform to a conclusion. I hope that I can reassure the House of the Government's intentions on that point.
I am sympathetic to the reappointment of the Procedure Committee, but we have a great deal of work from the Procedure Committee to be discharged before we engage in further obligations. Apart from the major report, we have a further eight reports of the Procedure Committee that have not been discussed by the House.
That is another Committee.

That may be.
Hon. Members on all sides have rightly raised the question of staffing the Committees, and that is a practical part of
the problem that we face. My right hon. Friend the Member for Taunton and my hon. Friends the Members for St. Marylebone (Mr. Baker) and Manchester, Withington (Mr. Silvester) were amongst those who raised the matter. If Committees of that order are set up, they must be adequately staffed. If one wills the end, one must will the means. The extent of the additional staff required can be assessed only when the Committees get under way in consultation with the Committees themselves and perhaps the Liaison Committee of Select Committee Chairmen, whatever form that may take. The House of Commons Commission will have the responsibility of ensuring that the Committees are properly supported in order to do their job.
More money.

Some more money, but not an excessive amount. One does not want to go to the extreme of the American Congress, but neither does one want to deny these Committees the essential tools to do their job.
I also fully accept that we have to act within the parameters of the economic policy of the Government, and in the present circumstances there can be no extravagance. I have received an assurance from the House authorities that existing staff are available to get the Committees under way forthwith—and I pay tribute to the House authorities for ensuring that that is so and for all the other selfless work that they do. We must see how the system develops and get it off to a good but reasonable start.
The terms of reference of these Committees has been mentioned. The interpretation of these will be a matter for the Committees themselves as well as for the House. The raison d'etre of the reform is that there should be departmental Committees and that if they are to exercise their functions they must find Ministers who are exercising responsibility. I hope that the Committees will act within a reasonably wide frame of reference and not confine themselves to the narrowest possible interpretation of their range of responsibility.
A further important point that was raised was the chairmanship of the Committees. That is for the Committees themselves. It is accepted that the Committees will have a Government majority on them.
It does not follow that that Government majority will take all the chairmanships. I hope that some kind of equitable arrangement will be worked out that is fair to everyone in the House.
We have had reference to Cabinet committees, and the right hon. Member for Bristol, South-East (Mr. Benn) and the hon. Member for Oldham, West (Mr. Meacher) touched on that point. There is much less secrecy about Cabinet committees under this Government than under any of their predecessors. On 24 May my right hon. Friend the Prime Minister, in answer to a question, published for the first time an official reference to the four standing committees of the Cabinet and named their chairmen. I do not know whether the right hon. Member for Bristol, South-East was aware of that. If he was not, it merely confirms my view that if one wants to keep a secret one should talk about it on the Floor of the House. If it desired to have something widely publicised, one should mention it in one of the secret party committees upstairs and the objective will be achieved.
I was interested in the remarks of the hon. Member for Oldham, West on his travails—so I took them to be—with the Civil Service. He, no doubt, has had his experience. The late Mr. Crossman had his. I can only say that in my experience of government, if a Minister knows his own mind and has the will to follow it through, he will get complete and loyal co-operation from the Civil Service. But, of course, if one dithers and is weak, nature abhors a vacuum and the Civil Service will obligingly step in to do the job.
The hon. Member for Oldham, West raised a question about the Committees and asked whether they would be allowed to see draft Bills. That is more a matter for the Committee dealing with public procedure. As I see these Committees working, I would have thought that members of the Committee, in the interchange of views and questions with Ministers and members of the Civil Service, would have a fairly good idea of the shape of coming legislation as the dialogue went on.
I mention Northern Ireland in passing. The right hon. Member for Down, South (Mr. Powell) raised two points. The first has been disposed of and related to
whether the Northern Ireland Standing Committee, under Standing Order 72A, would go on. It will, but I stress again that it is an ad hoc Committee which meets to consider particular matters referred to it. Secondly, the right hon. Gentleman asked whether the PCA should consider reports from Northern Ireland. I have to say that there are difficulties of a technical nature here. I give the right hon. Gentleman the assurance that I shall look into this matter and see what can be done to meet the objections he has raised.
I come now to deal with the various groups of amendments which the House has been considering. There is a difficulty of arrangement here. The debate has ranged widely, over nearly 40 amendments, and although they have been divided into groups they were not discussed in that order. I propose to deal with them in the order of selection by Mr. Speaker and to speak briefly on these 15 groups of amendments which we have been discussing.
The first group, consisting of amendments Nos. 3, 4, 5, 36, 21, 24, 30, 37 and 38, are all concerned with Scotland and a Select Committee of one kind or another for Scotland. I hope that hon. Members will not press this to a Division in view of the assurance I have been able to give, in principle, that the Government will set up a Scottish Select Committee but that the terms of reference and the composition should await the outcome of the all-party talks which we are about to launch on this matter.
rose—
I shall give way, but I have very little time to deal with all the points raised.

I hope the right hon. Gentleman realises that some Scottish Members have waited throughout the debate and unfortunately, for understandable reasons, have not been called. On this Scottish point, will he accept that there is a strong feeling in the House that a Select Committee on Scottish affairs should be dealt with in the context of the arguments we are having tonight about all the other departmental Committees? This has nothing to do with the need to produce something from the all-party talks on devolution. Devolution is about a transfer of power to Scotland
and the essence of it is a body which does not reflect the composition of this House but which reflects Scottish opinion. If the Select Committee to which the right hon. Gentleman refers is, as it must, to reflect the views in this House and the composition of this place, it must be decided tonight and must not be used as a fig leaf in some way to cover the lack of Conservative policy on devolution.

I think that that is a rather strange way of putting the argument, but I have said that I accept the principle of that Committee. It is obvious that, if one accepts the Committee in principle, it must be left to the Government to draft the actual amendment on a Committee of this importance, so I hope that the course I am advocating will be followed by the hon. Gentleman and others. It is up to them to decide, but I have to recommend my hon. Friends to vote against their proposal in those circumstances.
I pass on the next group of amendments, Nos. 6, 12 and 19. These concern essentially the proposed replacement of the Select Committee on Science and Technology by a new Select Committee on Science and Arts. This is the anti-C.P. Snow motion. We have had a declaration from the two Renaissance men—my hon. Friend the Member for Eastleigh (Mr. Price) and the hon. Member for Dewsbury (Mr. Ginsburg), Leonardo da Vinci and Benvenuto Cellini. I as a mere Victorian believe that we have two cultures and that they do not fit in very well together.
As regards scientific matters, the Procedure Committee, whilst accepting that there were arguments on both sides, came down in favour of the approach that scientific and technological matters should be examined within the context of departmental policies. Although it is ultimately for the House to decide, I must say that the establishment of a Committee on Science and Arts would cut across the whole general structure of the proposed new departmentally related Committees.
That argument applies to the next group of amendments—Nos. 11, 26 and 31—seeking the retention of the Select Committee on Science and Technology,
ably argued by my hon. Friend the Member for Havant and Waterloo (Mr. Lloyd), to whose technological and scientific knowledge I certainly pay deference. He was supported by the hon. Member for Bristol, North-East (Mr. Palmer), who has been such a distinguished Chairman of the Select Committee on Science and Technology. For the same reasons as I have given, I am unable to accept that argument. I believe that the new departmentally related Committees, as appropriate, will be fully alive to their scientific responsibility and I think that much of the most important work done in the past by the hon. Gentleman's Committee fell in fact within the scope of a single Department—the Department of Energy.
The fourth group of amendments—Nos. 8, 9, 10 and 39—in the names of the hon. Members for Fife, Central and for Sheffield, Heeley (Mr. Hooley), concern numbers on a Committee. We could argue a great deal about numbers, but may I give to the House the rationale behind the numbers which the Government have inserted in their recommendations? The present proposal for numbers on a Committee is based on an average of 10, which was the average recommendation by the Procedure Committee, with 11 members for the Committees with power to establish Sub-Committees, 10 members for those represented on the Nationalised Industries Sub-Committee, and 9 for the remainder, defence being the exception, in that case 10 being justified by that Committee's importance. Therefore, I cannot accept those amendments.
We come next to the fifth group—amendment No. 13—in the name of the hon. Member for Nottingham, West (Mr. English), for the inclusion of the Law Officers' Department. As I have said, there are grave objections to this because of judicial appointments, confidential communications between the Lord Chancellor and the judges on judicial matters, and related matters of that kind.
I received welcome support on that point from the right hon. and learned Member for Warley, West (Mr. Archer), who has experience in these matters. The point of the amendment is that it would include the matters which I have mentioned. There are no reservations in that amendment. Therefore, I am afraid that I cannot accept it. Indeed, there has not
been widespread support for it in this debate.
I turn to the next set of amendments, Nos. 14, 15, 16, 18 and 34. This was the group of amendments supported by my hon. Friend the Member for Brentwood and Ongar (Mr. McCrindle) dealing with the separation of trade from the Industry and Trade Committee. I am sorry to disappoint my hon. Friend, because I know he feels strongly about this matter and speaks with all the strength of experience, but the proposal in the motion is that the Department of Trade should be linked in a single Committee with the Department of Industry. I am afraid that I cannot agree to that amendment.
We then have before us amendment No. 27 to set up an official information Committee. That policy is not accepted by the Government. Our policy is to make as many background papers and analytical studies on major policy decisions as readily available as possible. We believe that these proposals are a major contribution to open government.
On the number of Sub-Committees—amendment No. 28 in the name of the hon. Member for Heeley—I am sympathetic but I am afraid that it is not possible to multiply the number of Sub-Committees. Then we have the proposals put forward by my hon. That is a matter for the Committee to decide. It would be possible for the Committee to set up a permanent Sub-Committee with one subject for the whole of the Parliament, or a permanent Sub-Committee with various changes of subject. I stress to my hon. Friend that that is a matter for the Committee and not for me.
The question of time is most important, but I do not think that it is desirable to write in an eight-day limit because that would tend to be a maximum. However, it is certainly my intention, and the intention of the Government, that substantially increased priority should be given for debates on Select Committee reports. There must be. It is an essential part of the package. But not every report will need a debate. We must have flexibility here. If that is not found satisfactory, we can look at it again. We can come back to it and see whether other arrangements need to be made.
With regard to powers, we have the amendment from the hon. Member for Fife, Central, supported by my hon. Friend the Member for Grantham and my hon. Friend the Member for Plymouth,
Drake (Miss Fookes). I take the view that the undertakings that I have given are sufficient. They take another view. It is summed up in "Henry IV", part 1, in a passage which will be familiar to you Mr. Speaker: Hotspur: I think there's no man speaks better Welsh: I'll to dinner. Mortimer: Peace … You will make him mad. Glendower: I can call spirits from the vasty deep. Hotspur: Why, so can I; or so can any man: But will they come, when you do call for them? I consider that the undertaking that I have given is sufficient to conjure up, not necessarily spirits, but at any rate Ministers. I hope that the House will accept that undertaking.
There is the question of the nomination of Select Committees (Committee of Selection). The hon. Member for Nottingham, West asked me why I had changed my mind on this. In fact, I did not change my mind. What I did was to put down a motion intended to apply to the 12 Committees in terms which were too wide and which covered all Select Committees. That was the recommendation of the Procedure Committee, I quite agree, but we did not intend to implement that recommendation all at once. We intended to implement it in relation to these Committees. That is the truth of the matter, and I dare say no one will believe me.
In conclusion, I say that here we are offered an opportunity, not a guarantee. The success of this experiment depends upon Members themselves. I hope that it will not be thought of as a vehicle for ministerial advancement by Ministers manque, of whom we have heard this evening. I hope that it will offer an alternative course of action, not to the exclusion of ministerial office but to let people move to and fro.
We are far too rigid in our legislature in these matters. There is a better example

in the United States, where people move in and out of politics, in and out of commerce, and from the academic world to politics. Let us have freedom of movement here. It is at any rate a start. It is, I believe, a good start, and I have been encouraged by the reception which the House has been kind enough to accord to these proposals.

I congratulate hon. Members on the interest they have shown. I congratulate them on the stamina they have shown by being here. It is a quality desiderative of the turf. That is not on the note which I have just received. That note says "Keep talking until one o'clock." Some horses can hold on and others cannot. May I say to hon. Members "Do not overdo it." It is the right of Members, of course, to divide the House. I have tried to answer as fully as I can the points that have been raised. I have tried to give assurances as fully as I can, and I hope that the House will respond to the lead I have given and support the motion.

I am delighted that my hon. Friend the Minister who is to reply to the debate has such a good record in the matter of pensioners' care.
The subject of death is often avoided by politicians, but the greatest certainty of life is that finally we have to die. If we are fortunate enough to be spared into old age, there comes that time when the mind must adjust to passing, and we think of the enormous cost of a funeral. It worries people to think of the cost of even a modest funeral.
This brings me to the need to raise the level of the death grant, which is today exactly what it was in 1967—a paltry £30. The history of the grant is a sad reflection on successive Governments, who since its introduction in 1949, at £20, have between them increased it only twice in 30 years. This is a disgrace.
It took nine years, from 1949 to 1958, to raise the grant by just £5, and another nine years, from 1958 to 1967, to raise the level again by only £5. Here we are in 1979, 12 years on, with no increase whatsoever.

It is a scandal that there has been no increase in the death grant for 12 years. Is it not an even greater scandal that tens of thousands of our most elderly pensioners are entitled to no death grant at all?

I am grateful to my hon. Friend for that intervention. Certainly there are limitations to the grant of which people are not aware. I was coming to this matter. For instance, when death occurs at age 95 or over in the case of men, or 90 or over in the case of women, no grant is paid. Therefore, my hon. Friend is right. Where death occurs at the age of 85 or over in the case of men
or 80 or over in the case of women, a reduced grant of £15 is paid. A grant of £15 is payable in respect of children aged 3 to 5 and £9 in respect of children under 3.
Let me deal with the human angle before returning to the cost, which is not often realised by the decision-makers here in Parliament. Many elderly people in my constituency—

It is not only Huddersfield. In many urban areas there is an ageing population. In my constituency, for instance, at the Todmorden end, many people are very old, and the age rate is higher than in many so-called retirement areas, such as Harrogate. Great distress is caused amongst an ageing population.

My hon. Friend is quite right. This is not a problem in my constituency alone, although of course I wish to refer to my constituency in this debate. It is a problem throughout the United Kingdom.
People are haunted by the prospect of a pauper's burial. A modest funeral these days can cost between £250 and £400, excluding charges for churches, cemeteries, doctors, legal costs and so on. Pensioners who truly wish to make provision for their own funeral are unable to keep up with inflation, which outpaces their ability to save from their pensions. Years ago pensioners took out insurance for pennies or tuppence, and thought that when the policies matured they would provide enough money at least to bury them. But in this inflationary world it has not proved to be enough. This is very sad. Pensioners are cutting down on their food and heating because they cannot save sufficient funds.

Does the hon. Gentleman agree that many pensioners, in cutting down on the cost of heating and food, are hastening their death and will regrettably have to meet the cost of their funeral far earlier than they might otherwise have done?

The hon. Member is right. Although I have no concrete evidence, we hear of hypothermia in the winter, and it must be the case. If elderly people cut down on their heating that would be the result for a number of them.
It is sad and silly, but we cannot say that they are unwise. I am pleased to say that we cannot yet rule the hearts of the elderly from Westminster.
I do not wish to take away the responsibility for funerals from individuals and their families. The State should not have to pay to bury people. Families wish to do that for their elderly folk and elderly people wish to try to save sufficient money. I am trying to highlight the problems so that the death grant can be made a more meaningful contribution.
I ask the Government to consider the following action. First, I ask them to restore the death grant to its original 1949 value of £132. That is based on the general index of retail prices. Secondly, there should be an immediate abolition of the age restriction.
The cost of paying the grant at the higher level will be about £55 million a year and the extension of the grant to those very elderly people excluded would cost a further £12 million a year. The House will agree that £67 million is a small item in our total national budget. I hope that we can move towards a situation in which people can preserve dignity even in death with the help of us all and in the fullness of time with the help of the Minister.

speech.speakername: The Under-Secretary of State for Health and Social Security (Mrs. Lynda Chalker)
speech.p:
I should first, like to thank my hon. Friend the Member for Huddersfield, West (Mr. Dickens) for raising this subject because of the welcome opportunity it gives us to look at the national insurance death grant.
It is welcome, first, because of the concern which has been expressed over the grant in many quarters, not least by the all-party committee concerned with the affairs of pensioners, led by my hon. Friend the Member for Brighton, Kemp-town (Mr. Bowden) and others. In the short period since taking office, I have received from many honourable Members and the public representations that reflect the concern expressed by various organisations and many individuals in different parts of the country.
However, it is also welcome because many years have elapsed since the grant was introduced and that is, in itself, suffi-
cient reason to suggest that there is a case for looking at it afresh.
The death grant as introduced by the National Insurance Act 1946 was an entirely new feature of State insurance which originated in the proposals made by the wartime Beveridge report for a "universal funeral grant". The report justified the inclusion of such a benefit in compulsory State insurance on the grounds that that was administratively the simplest—and probably financially cheapest—way of meeting a universal need.
The grant introduced by the Act was a straightforward lump sum payment made on the death of a contributor, his spouse or children. Amendments were later introduced to include the handicapped adult relatives of contributors. Since the grant was a new benefit it was decided that only people who contributed under the scheme should be eligible for it. Hence, those who were over pensionable age at July 1948 were ineligible and those within 10 years of pensionable age qualified for only half the standard grant. This is the point raised by my hon. Friend the Member for Kemptown, to which I shall return.
There was a simple contribution condition to be met and this was, in later years, relaxed even more. It now requires at most the payment of 25 weeks' contributions—even less with employed earnings above the minimum level. This is a test which very few people fail to satisfy. But the grant still stands at £30.
When the grant was first introduced at a rate of £20 it went some way towards the cost of a simple funeral, but we should note that, in framing the legislation, it was decided quite deliberately that, unlike Beveridge's proposals, the grant should not be linked to the cost of funerals. It was, as I say, simply a lump sum payable on the death of most contributors and their families. It was a contribution towards the cost of a funeral. Even if it was not absolutely universal, the grant was available to most contributors to meet a need which, at that time, was felt to be widespread.
When the first grants were paid in July 1949 there were reduced amounts payable for children as well as those who, because of age, qualified for only half the standard rate. In 1958 the standard rate
was increased to £25 and in 1967 to £30, with corresponding increase in the reduced rates. The rates have remained unchanged since 1967.
It is obvious, therefore, that the grant has failed to keep up with inflation and that its real value has fallen over the years. For example, based on the movement of the index of retail prices to May 1979, the latest month for which figures are available, the grant would have to be increased to £133·7 to have the same real value as it did in July 1949. To equal its value when last increased in October 1967 the grant would have to be £103·78.
Similarly, if one compares the level of the grant with funeral expenses, it has clearly fallen behind. It is hard to be certain about the figures, as funeral costs vary widely throughout the country, but it seems that in 1949 the grant met about 60 per cent. of the cost and in 1967 about 35 per cent. Nowadays, with the average cost of even a simple funeral probably about £200, the grant contributes 15 per cent. or less towards the cost. It has been suggested that, because of the declining value of the grant, it ought to be increased. We must, therefore, consider the costs which would be involved.
The present grant costs about £16 million a year. To increase the grant to restore the real value it had in 1967 would mean spending an extra £40 million a year, while to restore the real 1949 value would cost an extra £55 million a year. To increase the grant to £200, as has peen suggested by some correspondents, would cost an extra £91 million a year.
As my hon. Friend has said, these figures do not take account of the groups who, on account of their age, are excluded from the grant or qualify for only a reduced rate. Whatever justification there might have been in 1949 for excluding them because of the contributory principle underlying the grant, it could now be argued that these people have suffered more than most from the effects of inflation, particularly in recent years. They include many of the individuals who most need the help of the State. To include them in the present grant would require an extra £10 million a year, on the basis of the 1949 value, or, on the basis of a £200 grant, about an extra £17 million a year.
To restore the value of the grant would, therefore, involve considerable extra sums of money. At the same time, however, I very much appreciate the concern which has been expressed about the grant. I have, for example, received letters from those who are involved with pensioners—not just organisations which write to us frequently but individuals such as home helps working with elderly people who express clearly the worry of elderly people about this matter. There is no doubt that many elderly people are frightened about dying and about what will happen to them.
It is because of the concern which has been expressed that I feel that the Government must give consideration to the whole problem of the grant's future role, not simply to paying more to those already entitled to the grant.
Of course, people would be helped it we were to increase the grant across the board. We shall consider this, but I am sure that it is not necessarily the best answer to the problem. It can be argued that, although the death grant is insufficient for many, it is not needed by some; that is to say, the grant is at present paid in cases where it is no longer essential. If that is the case, I question whether it would be right to increase the amount paid to everybody, without reconsidering the purpose of the grant and the needs it should meet.
In fact, to obtain more information on the payment of funeral expenses and the part played by the death grant, the research branch of my Department has carried out an independent survey. It has not yet been published, but it might be appropriate if I say a little about the results which seem to be emerging.
First, it notes that there has been, since the war, a trend towards more simple, modest funeral practices. Some of the more expensive customs of the past have become the exception and burials are now less common than cremations. It records that most of those in the sample surveyed received payment of a life assurance policy following the death, to which were added payments from superannuation and other sources such as the savings of the deceased. Very few of the respondents said that they had any difficulty in finding money to meet the costs; 93 per cent. of them said that they had no difficulties.
The survey makes the point that the payment of funeral expenses—despite the decline in the value of the death grant—has ceased to be the major social problem of the scale experienced 40 or 50 years ago. The reason for this may lie in social factors. There are changes in funeral customs. There has been a relative steady fall in the relative cost of a funeral when compared with wages, and there is a decline in the number of people dying in extreme poverty. But that does not diminish the problem for those who are in difficulty. It is shown by the genuine concern apparent in letters I receive.
However, the problem is a different one from that which had to be faced when
the death grant was introduced in 1948. As the problem has changed, we must look more widely than at a simple increase in death grant if an appropriate solution is to be found. I assure my hon. Friends and others who have written to tell me their thoughts on the matter that this wider consideration which is taking place is bound to take time and regretfully we have been forced to conclude that we cannot consider any action on the grant this year. Nevertheless, I should like to assure the House that we are considering the matter as urgently as possible and that as soon as we can make an announcement we shall certainly do so.
